the ocean has a signiﬁcant trend in Chl-a by 2030, and only
31% by 2100. The high interannual variability in Chl-a (Fig.
results in few regions having a sufﬁciently strong signal for
the trend to be detectable (a similar conclusion was found
). However, does this mean that there are
only small changes occurring in the ocean ecosystem and
biogeochemistry over the course of the 21st century in this
scenario? We consider other optically important constituents of
Our model suggests that detrital matter will show an even
slower and less obvious signal than Chl-a (Fig.
CDOM will have a stronger signal (Fig.
ocean showing a signiﬁcant trend by 2100. The increased
bleaching of CDOM in the more stratiﬁed surface waters leads
to this stronger signal relative to Chl-a.
and more signiﬁcant trends over the course of the century
e) than any of the other metrics that we have considered
to this point. A total of 50% of the ocean shows a signal of change
by 2100, and even by 2040, 21% of the ocean has an unambiguous
signal. In this model the community structure is determined by
biogeochemical functional groups; in which differences between
the groups are set by their nutrient requirements and roles in
biogeochemical cycles (see Methods). These different functional
groups also have distinct accessory pigments that lead to different
combination of phytoplankton that coexist (the community) at
any point in the ocean has a strong impact on the optics of the
and changes to the communities will have an
Though these ﬁndings are informative about potential changes
in the oceans, these are not as useful from the perspective of the
properties that ocean colour satellites actually measure. Each of
these quantities, i.e. actual Chl-a, CDOM, detritus and commu-
nity composition, are quantities that can only be measured in situ.
A more practical question would be: What is the percentage of the
ocean area showing a signiﬁcant trend in globally observable
quantities at different intervals over the 21st century?
Optics and ocean colour trends and time of emergence
emergence of the unambiguous climate change signal (Figs.
g). We ﬁnd that the reﬂectance trend in the blue

a) as already seen in the difference plots
). However, in some regions (e.g. central North Atlantic
gyre) other optical constituents become more important and anti-
correlation is not as clear (see e.g. Fig.
a, b). In regions of the
largest Chl-a trends, the 475 nm (blue) waveband
Globally, all wavebands of the model reﬂectance (Fig.
a stronger trend than the individual optically important water
changes. However, given that the model underestimates the
natural variability especially in the high wavebands (Fig.
focus only on our results for the lower (<600 nm) wavelength
The strongest signal is in the blue-green range (in our model
the two 25 nm wavebands centred at 475 and 500 nm). These
wavebands show a clear signal over 50% of the ocean by the end
of the century. The strongest signal of trend was found over the
wavelengths spanning from 487 to 512 nm, with 63% of the ocean
providing a signiﬁcant signal by 2100. These are the wavebands
where there is the least interannual variability in the model
b, Supplementary Fig. 4). This matches what is found in the
OC-CCI product where interannual variability is lowest in the
490 and 510 nm wavebands. These wavebands also lie on the edge
of the wave-space between the strong absorption by CDOM in
) and where the impact of absorption by
water starts to become more signiﬁcant in the higher wavebands.
These bands are likely to be most sensitive to changes in
community composition. The low interannual variability together
with sensitivity to changes in all water constituents suggest that
these wavebands in the real world satellite sensors (490 and 510
nm) might be the ﬁrst measurements to detect climate change
The metric of true colour, the hue angle, which is composed of
the full visible reﬂectance spectra does not show a particularly

sample periods are shown. In addition, we only show regions that were ice
